Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: CalBug, an Interactive Database Using Arthropods to Examine Impacts of Climate Change and Habitat Modification
Award.AbstractNarration: Habitat modification and climate change are occurring at unprecedented rates globally. While tools to predict future environments have become increasingly sophisticated, there is little understanding of how biodiversity will respond to novel environments. The current proposal represents collaboration among eight entomological collections in California to digitize specimens and thus allow assessment of how distributions of organisms have been modified through environmental change. It makes use of a long history of entomological collecting in the state to develop a database of approximately 1 million georeferenced specimens collected at focal localities over the last century. The specimen data will be used in geospatial analyses to understand the relationship between the distribution of species and the type and extent of habitat modification. The project will serve as a model for integrating data across multiple institutions and incorporating the combined data within a geospatial framework. Human-driven environmental change has already caused huge impacts on biological systems. To understand how biodiversity will respond to environmental change in the future, we must learn from their responses in the past. A large amount of data is available on organisms that existed in environments before and after habitat modification over the last century; however, much of this information is hidden within museum collections, held on labels among millions of specimens. The proposed digitization and georeferencing of these collections will transform research capability and access to information by both scientists and the public. It will result in a fully georeferenced database of target taxa from natural reserves throughout California that will be searchable and available on web-accessible maps. The proposal includes entomological museums of all sizes and audiences in California and provides education of graduate and undergraduate students in taxonomy and systematic, coupled with the use of bioinformatics and geospatial modeling as applied to habitat modification and climate change.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Habitat modification and climate change are occurring at unprecedented rates globally. California has played a lead role in establishing the science and policy necessary to understand and mitigate the impacts of such change. While tools to predict future environments have become increasingly sophisticated, there is still little understanding of how biodiversity will respond to novel environments. Arthropods can serve as fine scale indicators of response to habitat modification as a huge amount of data is available on individuals that existed in environments before and after habitat modification over the last century. However, much of this information is hidden within museum collections, held on labels among millions of specimens. Thus, our digitization and georeferencing effort transforms research capability and access to information by both scientists and the public by providing a georeferenced database of target taxa from

natural reserves throughout California that is searchable and available on web accessible maps. This award is a collaboration among 8 California entomological collections to develop a database of georeferenced specimens collected at focal localities over the last century. These data are used to look at impacts of habitat modification and climate change in California over the last century. Our specific goals were to:

1) digitize approximately 1.1 million records among a diverse set of major groups of California terrestrial arthropods across 8 collections, approx. 11% from the California State Collection of Arthropods (CSCA). The CSCA data is at various stages of upload and databasing in the main databae (approx. 16% have been databased directly (ca. 18,500), another 30% have been imaged (ca. 45,000)). An additional 50,000+ species records (currently in Excel format) have been cleaned-up and data-field matched from the California Department of Food and Agriculture's (CDFA) PDR (Pest Damage Record) database (which represents an additional 42%). Another 28,400+ species records of California Therevidae and Acroceridae (Diptera) from Mandala (a database of the world's therevids and acrocerids) are undergoing the same treatment. These database records will be uploaded directly to the Calbug database shortly.

 

2) georeference the specimen level arthropod biodiversity data (approx. 20% complete). Note, the records from CDFA's PDR database, and from Mandala, are already geocoded. For the specimens databased directly from CSCA, nearly 40% are geocoded.

 

3) Use the specimen data, which includes those from CSCA, in geospatial technology and analyses to understand the relationship between the distribution of species, and the precise nature and extent of habitat modification.

 

As the principal organizing institution (UC Berkeley) has received a No Cost Extension, the Calbug project will continue to develop and be added to over the coming year. It is expected that by the end of the project next year there will be ca. 1.1 million georeferenced records available for the focal insect groups from all over California.
